titleStmt.title: Gravestone of James and Martha Jarvis

support.p: This is a stone (possibly sandstone) gravestone ( 74 cm 145 cm 8 cm ).

supportDesc.condition: Good condition, all text visible and legible

layoutDesc.layout: The text is carved onto the gravestone and is centred on the top two thirds of the gravestone. There is no border and the field has a simple rectangle shape with a rounded top.

handDesc.summary: The text varies in size, with the largest letters used for the names.

div.ab:
SACRED
TO THE MEMORY OF
JAMES JARVIS
OF THIS PARISH
BAKER
DIED MAY THE 18TH 1826.
AGED 58 YEARS.
ALSO
MARTHA.
HIS WIFE.
DIED NOVR. THE 3RD 1825.
AGED 65 YEARS.
SHALT NOT THE JUDGE OF ALL THE EARTH
DO RIGHT.

div.p: Shortened months have been given in their full forms in the 'translation'

Sacred to the memory of James Jarvis of this parish, baker. Died May the 18th 1826, aged 58 years. Also Martha, his wife, died November the 3rd 1825, aged 65 years. Shalt not the judge of all the Earth do right.

This nineteenth century gravestone lists the names of two occupants, a James Jarvis and his wife Martha, also presumably taking the surname Jarvis. James Jarvis was a baker in the parish. From the age and the date of death, we can calculate that James Jarvis would have been born c. 1768 and Martha would have been born c. 1758. Its location directly outside the entrance to the church suggests a certain level of status within the community, with it being place near the prominent family tombs. The expression 'Sacred to the memory of' is a phrase which is used commonly among other graves of this time within this churchyard. The phrase which ends the text on the tombstone in lines 13-14 is a direct quote from Genesis 18:25.
